articles.headline: ‘Never Seen Anything Like It’: Cars Line Up for Miles at Food Banks
articles.snippet: Millions are flooding a charitable system that was never intended to handle a nationwide crisis.
articles.abstract: Millions are flooding a charitable system that was never intended to handle a nationwide crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Omaha, a food pantry that typically serves as few as 100 people saw 900 show up on a single day. In Jonesboro, Ark., after a powerful tornado struck, a food bank received less than half the donations it expected because nervous families held on to what they had. And in Washington State and Louisiana, the National Guard has been called in to help pack food boxes and ensure that the distributions run smoothly.

articles.headline: Zoom Rushes to Improve Privacy for Consumers Flooding Its Service
articles.snippet: The features that allowed companies to hop on videoconferences also made it easy for trolls to hijack meetings and harass students.
articles.abstract: The features that allowed companies to hop on videoconferences also made it easy for trolls to hijack meetings and harass students.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last month, the Zoom videoconferencing service has emerged as the communication lifeline of the coronavirus pandemic. But the convenience fueling Zoom’s explosive popularity has come at a price.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer, Nicole Perlroth and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Why Republicans Are So Afraid of Vote-by-Mail
articles.snippet: Public health officials recommend absentee ballots to keep people safe. But President Trump and his party, without evidence, portray expanded voting measures as ripe for fraud.
articles.abstract: Public health officials recommend absentee ballots to keep people safe. But President Trump and his party, without evidence, portray expanded voting measures as ripe for fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump and his Republican allies are launching an aggressive strategy to fight what many of the administration’s own health officials view as one of the most effective ways to make voting safer amid the deadly spread of Covid-19: the expanded use of mail-in ballots.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Maggie Haberman and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Optimism Is Less Distant as Global Coronavirus Battle Rages On
articles.snippet: Scientists say drastic shifts in behavior appear to be having an effect in the pandemic, though they say the death toll will continue to mount and caution against drawing any sweeping conclusions.
articles.abstract: Scientists say drastic shifts in behavior appear to be having an effect in the pandemic, though they say the death toll will continue to mount and caution against drawing any sweeping conclusions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world began this week to see small but encouraging signs that concerted efforts to drastically change human behavior — to suspend daily routines by staying at home — are slowing the insidious spread of the novel coronavirus, which has killed tens of thousands and sickened more than a million others across several continents.

articles.headline: The Humble Phone Call Has Made a Comeback
articles.snippet: The volume of phone calls has surged more than internet use as people want to hear each other’s voices in the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The volume of phone calls has surged more than internet use as people want to hear each other’s voices in the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alyssa MacKenzie, 32, rarely used her smartphone to make phone calls, apart from the occasional conversation for her work as a disability rights advocate.

articles.headline: In Scramble for Coronavirus Supplies, Rich Countries Push Poor Aside
articles.snippet: Developing nations in Latin America and Africa cannot find enough materials and equipment to test for coronavirus, partly because the United States and Europe are outspending them.
articles.abstract: Developing nations in Latin America and Africa cannot find enough materials and equipment to test for coronavirus, partly because the United States and Europe are outspending them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Crates of masks snatched from cargo planes on airport tarmacs. Countries paying triple the market price to outbid others. Accusations of “modern piracy” against governments trying to secure medical supplies for their own people.

articles.headline: ‘Sudden Black Hole’ for the Economy With Millions More Unemployed
articles.snippet: Jobless claims now exceed 16 million as shutdowns from the coronavirus pandemic widen and problems with getting benefits persist.
articles.abstract: Jobless claims now exceed 16 million as shutdowns from the coronavirus pandemic widen and problems with getting benefits persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the coronavirus outbreak shutting businesses in every state, fresh evidence of the economic devastation was delivered Thursday as a government report showed that 6.6 million more workers had lost their jobs.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: These Groups Are Giving Out Unemployment Advice. Their Expertise? Personal Experience.
articles.snippet: Across the country, unemployed workers are setting up online communities to help navigate the nightmare of crashed websites and confusing regulations.
articles.abstract: Across the country, unemployed workers are setting up online communities to help navigate the nightmare of crashed websites and confusing regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since she was furloughed from her job at a go-kart track in Las Vegas, Cyara Neel has been working harder than ever.
